threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Welcome to /diy/, a place to:

Post and discuss /diy/ projects, ask questions regarding /diy/ topics and exchange ideas and techniques.

Please keep in mind:
- This is a SFW board. No fleshlights or other sex toys.
- No weapons. That goes to /k/ - Weapons. The workmanship and techniques involved in creating objects which could be used as weapons or the portion of a weapons project that involves them (e.g., forging steel for a blade, machining for gunsmithing, what epoxy can I use to fix my bow) may be discussed in /diy/, but discussing weapon-specific techniques/designs or the actual use of weapons is disallowed. Things such as fixed blade knives or axes are considered tools, things such as swords, guns or explosives are considered weapons.
- No drugs or drug paraphernalia (See Global Rule 1). If you want to discuss something that could involve such things (e.g., carving a tobacco pipe from wood) that's fine, but make sure it's /diy/ related and doesn't involve drugs or it will result in deletion/ban.

Helpful links:
https://sites.google.com/site/diyelmo/
http://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Some friendly suggestions for posting:
- First ask Google, then ask /diy/. Your question will probably be better received if you do so.
- List available resources (tools, materials, budget, time, etc.)
- Try to use pictures and explain the goal, if possible
- Be patient, this is a slow board; your thread will be around for days.
- Share your results! /diy/ loves to see problems solved and projects completed!

>I'm new to electronics. Where to get started?
It is an art/science of applying principles to requirements.
Find problem, learn principles, design and verify solution, build, test, post results, repeat.

>Incredibly comprehensive list of electronics resources:

Additional resources below:

>Project ideas:

>>2505185
I will offer slightly different advice on height, make it a little higher than that, it is easy to lop an inch off, not so easy to add an inch, this lets you find the work height best for you. Everyone is a little different in how they work and what works for them, for me that anons height would be too high as I want to be able to comfortably kneel on the stock for ripping, with 2" thick stock my foot on the ground will be quite unhappy being stuck on its toes if the bench were that high. Make it a bit higher than needed, use it some and figure out how it is off, adjust, repeat a few times to perfection.

My next bench will be higher though, flush straight legs on one side which can take my bench hooks for jointing wide work and the other side will be flaired out from the bench, there will be a shelf a few inches off the ground that I can put my foot on when ripping which will add a fair amount of stability getting all my weight on the bench itself. This is how I kind of work now but the legs on both sides of my bench flare out so no exploiting the one side for bench hooks and jointing. The bench itself will be designed around my tool chest which will fit on that shelf when I am not using it. I might make that this weekend actually.

>>2504540
Whole lot of what make Japan 'Japanese' is sort of tied into a lot of cultural practices, skills and all that shit- which they do claim is very important to them and why they've gone down the path they have when it comes to their comparatively homogeneous society that tends to play on the whole traditional art, practice, religion and crafts.
>just as a disclaimer- I'm not a weeb, but my wife is a bit so you're getting to suffer with me now as well
I mean if your traditional jap tea ceremony means sitting on some astroturf under a cheap collapsible pergola with a chinese aluminium kettle and some red party cups... you'd kind of have to admit that its all gone a bit fuckywucky somewhere! But every part of something like that has some traditional production in JP- the iron kettle, the ceramic cups, tatami mats, the tea and probably even the structure will have had some sort of long term traditional production locally. If that all disappears into cheap imports then its going to take fucking ages to make it all again if it skips 2-3generations of craftsman. Even then, it will probably take another 2gens after that to get it out of the amateur leagues.

I mean if it matters that little to them, it dies out I guess and they can go figure it out themselves. Things like wage subsidies and trade discounts in protected markets aren't that expensive and its done in the western countries as well to preserve a lot of art and architecture, a lot of our more traditional crafts and artisan trades tended to get lost in industrialisation and various other events. So its more of an eccentricity to keep some stuff around like a protected species as we've more or less moved a bit too far forward

Here we discuss microcontrollers, SBCs and microcontroller accessories, such as Atmel mega and tiny AVRs (Arduinos), PICs, ARM boards such as blue/black pill STM32, ESP8266/32s, Raspberry Pi, and others.

For general electronics questions (power supplies, level shifting, motor driving, etc.) please ask /ohm/.

>where can I find verified quality microcontrollers and other electronic sensors or parts
digikey.com
mouser.com
arrow.com
newark.com

>but that's too expensive
aliexpress.com (many parts here are fake, particularly specific parts out of stock in the above sites)
lcsc.com

>I need a part that does X and Y, with Z specifications. How can I find it?
use digikey or mouser's parametric part search. Then purchase from one of the sellers listed above.

>how do I get started with microcontrollers, where should I start?
There is no defined starting point, grab a book and start reading or buy an arduino off ebay/amazon and start messing around. There are a plethora of examples online to get started.

>resources:
https://github.com/kitspace/awesome-electronics

You start by finding a free socket on the fuse box that is only 12v when the ignition switch is on or accessory. the ground wire for the light can be wired to the chassis.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2505235
As long as you're only using 150-200W loads, that is probably fine. Beyond that, the battery wires (the blue/brown ones) are way too thin, the connectors are too small. You should fuse each battery's output right at the terminal with maybe 15A fuses. Saw the battery board in two, coat the surface in thick blob of solder and isolate + and - (wrap them in tape or heatshrink or something).
If you had some money to put into it, EASUN has very cheap ~200 euro 12V-24V solar inverters that have everything included, the option of connecting solar panels to charge the battery, also direct UPS switching and battery management.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Penny expander here. Not owning a vehicle is a big money save. Find a living space within walking distance to work and all necessities. Invest in a bike or electric scooter if it's suitable to your area. I happen to live right up the road from a dollar store so that's helped with a lot of little random things. Get all furniture/appliances second hand locally. Craigslist seems to be full of people trying to make a buck but I've found a lot of stuff for next to nothing (if not nothing) on Facebook Marketplace. Make friends with someone with a pickup truck. Cook crockpot meals and make several servings at a time so you can heat up leftovers on subsequent days. Walmart has the cheapest groceries I've found. For clothes, I buy jeans on eBay; can get a good fitting and looking lightly used pair for $20 or less even if you're picky like me if you put the time into it. If you don't care so much how you look it'll be real easy. I just wear one pair of jeans until they wear through and then replace them. For shirts I dig through the clearance racks at Kohl's. My local store always has several large racks full of clearance items. It's like its own section of the store. Kohl's always has some 15-20% off coupon active at any time; just look it up online and they'll scan it off your phone at the counter. Nothing wrong with thrift stores but I haven't had a lot of luck with my local ones. That's all that comes to mind at the moment. When I need something that isn't food it's mostly a matter of recognizing where to look for it: Amazon, eBay, Marketplace, Walmart, etc.

threads.com: As I’ve began sanding out the tang I’ve run into a problem- for the habaki and handle to fit I need to have a sharp 90° angle at the transition between the tang and blade. I only have a hacksaw, cheap Walmart belt sander and file set to work with, and this knife started out as a file so the other files just skate on its surfaces. What’s the easiest/cheapest way to get that 90° angle? Thanks in advance

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2504763
All you need is a fire to anneal it, you can do it in a grill, get the coals good and hot and the bury it in them. But two tin cans, one large and one the standard size, some sand and a propane torch is all you need to make a little forge suitable for annealing and heat treating small things like you are working on.
>>2504811
A grinding disc would be more suitable for your needs than a cutoff wheel. But you really are best off just building a simple forge.
>>2504807
I started out this way, there was a grinder and some old files left in a house I moved into, made some chisels. eventually did temper, still use them. One of these days I will make a few chisels that are that hard, despite the brittleness they were fantastic for parring and the brittleness is not much of and issue there. The flex of a proper parring chisel is lost there but you don't always need that and when you don't having that insanely hard steel is great.

All the info you need about 3D-printing: https://pastebin.com/AKqpcyN5
>Your print failed? Go to:
https://www.simplify3d.com/support/print-quality-troubleshooting/

If that doesn't help you solve your print problems, please post:
>A picture of the failed part
>Printer make & model
>Filament type/brand
>Slicer & slicer settings

>What printer should I buy? [Last updated 12-20-2021]
Under 250 USD: kingroon KP3L, Sovol sv01, Creality Ender 3 (v2), Anycubic Mega S
Under 500 USD: Qidi X-One2, Creality CR-10, Anycubic Vyper, Prusa Mini,
Under 1000 USD: Prusa i3, Flashforge creator pro 2
Over 1000 USD: e3d toolchanger, Ultimaker, Qidi X-CF Pro, Build your own Voron, Prusa XL (lol enjoy the wait)
SLA: Anycubic Photon, Elegoo Mars, Prusa SL1, Formlabs Form 3, Creality HALOT-ONE
Instead of buying a new printer, you could consider building your own: https://reprap.org/wiki/

>Where can I get free things to print?
https://www.thingiverse.com/
https://thangs.com/
https://grabcad.com/
https://google.com/
https://printables.com/
https://www.yeggi.com/

>What CAD software should I use?
Variants of professional parametric CAD programs such as Solidworks (lol paying for software), Fusion360, Inventor, Onshape, TinkerCAD, and AutoCAD may be free depending on your profession, level of piracy and definition of ''free''.
Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

How do you make a Centennial Light Bulb? Googling it obviously brings up no DIYs for it, but if it was made in the 1890s, then obviously it's possible that you can make one yourself today. The whole reason they were built to be shortlasting is solely because it wasn't good for business (understandable). But I'm fucking tired of changing my lightbulbs just for them to blow after like a week.

Does anyone know the "archaic knowledge that was lost to time" required to make one?

Here's a video on it:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZLhe9tD6f98

And the Wikipedia:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centennial_Light

There's no mention on how it works, and the video itself says they're having to "study it" to find out how exactly it does. I'm not exactly looking for an exact replication, but even a light-bulb that lasts a fraction of the time this one has would be fucking awesome.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2502549
Get a standard LED bulb and put in a resistor to run it very very underpowered. It will last essentially forever

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2502549
>Does anyone know the "archaic knowledge that was lost to time" required to make one?

Here is how you can make LED bulbs which last forever:
https://www.fingers-welt.de/phpBB/viewtopic.php?f=14&t=19109&p=418276#p418276

The trick is basically to lower the power output considerably so that the LEDs do not overheat. This way, you can make them last forever.

If you really want to use incandescent bulbs:
- buy 230V bulbs and run them on 110V
- Put a diode in one cable of the two connected to the bulb.
This will lower their output and increase the lifespan.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2504168
a common failure point in led lights is the driver, not the leds...you are going to want to use high quality components for the power supply, or maybe have like 5 drivers in there, each driving alternating leds? that way, when 1 set fails, the other 4 will still run! its like having 5 light bulbs in one!

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2504688
The drivers failing pisses me off.
I life in an area where the power goes out frequently and brownouts have killed about 5 of my 120V LEDs in the last 4 years.
I've started using the fake filament LEDs that are basically 60 or so in series.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2504688
I have repaired 6 pieces 10W LED flood lights recently, and in 5 of them, the driver did still work. But it is mostly the caps that fail in drivers, just replace them with a -con capacitor, like Rubycon, Nichicon etc. with a high temperature rating. And a slightly higher voltage rating.

Don't pretend that you know everything. If you don't know how to do something, say so, ask for help. If you don't have time to do the job right, you don't have time to do it over.

Treat your tools with respect and take care of them. Despite all the nanny state safety bullshit, blue collar work is inherently fucking dangerous. Most injuries on the job are due to trying to be He-Man, or using the wrong tool for the job, not understanding the tool, or the tool is in poor condition. Don't ever remove the safety guards on something no matter what the old salty dogs tell you.

threads.com: I own a military surplus store with a militaria museum. We use several vintage showcases, a few of which have significant scratches, one to the point of being almost hazy. I've been looking at options, including a headlight buffing kit, toothpaste, or other scratch removal products, some of which are around $100. I just want to be sure whatever I buy actually works. Any anons have experience that could recommend products/methods? Did my best to image the scratches for examples.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2504348
This is what I was looking for. Thanks.

>>2504342
I have looked into it. A couple I have in storage have significant damage, and to replace 8x2.5 1/4 beveled plate is over $400 per. Not going to do that for six or seven cases. I came here hoping for a quick, reasonably priced solution. If there is none I'm fine with leaving them as is.

>>2504351
No Zyklon B, but I do have a back room that looks a bit similar.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2504426
YW. For glass that's hazy/foggy from abrasion and pitting you might try applying a wax product made especially for glass, picrel is the old school standard that isn't made anymore but there are similar products that go on like car wax and buff off that can really help rejuvenate the shine and fill microscopic damage that makes the surface appear cloudy.

FWIW, if you have been quoted
$400 for 96"×30"×1/4" beveled glass that's a pretty good price...personally for a case top I'd go at least 5/16" if it's just annealed glass and it could be made to fit.
Thing is though that glass prices are exponential as it gets thicker so you can't count on 125% thicker only going up that much, it might be $600 (150%) instead.

All that said, the dirtyxsecret about glass fabrication and sales is that you can pay practically anything for any size/thickness or edge treatment, tempering, etc....there's no real industry pricing standards and shipping/handling and risk of breakage are how costs are figured, the material itself isxtge least of it. Busy shops and larger operators can usually spread those costs out so always get multiple quotes from a bunch of shops...in my experience the best price on mirror, or tempered glass, or dual glazing, or decorative edgework or textured and specialty glass will almost never be from the same place, everyone has loss leaders and has other stuff at a premium.
It's like buying meat, prices are all over the place and the cheap supermarket may charge more than a real butcher on one thing while the butcher charges 10× as much for something else.

>>2504680
Not waxes specifically, when I worked with etched glass we used to use oil based furniture polish to even it out when people got greasy fingerprints on it, and anything like that or silicone will do the same to cut the whitishness of that kind of damage...the wax is nice because it lasts a lot longer.
You might even try a good car wax, worst case scenario is you strip it off and as far as I can tell the main difference is that the glass stuff is more liquid and easier to buff off than a heavier or stickier formulation like furniture paste wax with beeswax in it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2502388
Depends on the climate and environment. If your country or county is rich in cob, it's a cheap material and depending on the way it's built, it can be easier to build alone than laying bricks. The best climate is if you live in a normal or dryer climate.
As methods, you can look up example traditional hungarian cob houses. They used (sometimes not) woven net as basic wall structure, and layer by layer plastered cob on it. They made half meter thickness usually. The positive side to it that summer was always cool inside and the air quality is top notch, never dry, and with the good lime plaster it never gets wet. Bad side is that they had to make huge roof over hanger to avoid wetness from rain. They painted the wall yearly again as protection.
An other, more geometrical method: Look up japanese cob wall installations. They build it wall by wall or panel by panel where they use a wire mesh so it holds the cob and gives more flexibility to the walls, but the weight holding structure is wood there.

threads.sub: Replacing my 12v car battery with 18650s without a BMS
threads.com:
We all know charging 18650s above 4.2v is bad.

Lets say my car alternator charges the lead acid battery to 14v.

If I parallel 4 x 18650 at 4.2v the maximum safe voltage would be 16.8v. This is above the max voltage the alternator outputs, which is 14v.

So at 14v each 18650 cell would be at only 3.5v, and I don't have to worry about overcharging since once the 18650s are at 14v they simply won't accept any more current since the voltage isn't rising.

Now if I add multiple parallel banks of 4 x 18650s I would have each cell at 3.5v but lot of available current, enough to start a car.

So doing it this way, I figure I don't need a BMS since there is no way the 18650s can be overcharged. Tell me if I am wrong?

That's not how electricity works. Your inverter will use the amount of power it needs to use even if the panels are able to provide more.

Think of an electrical device as a vaccuum rather than thinking of the electrical supply as a pump. The panels aren't forcing electricity into the inverter, the inverter is pulling electricity from the panels. And it will only pull as much as it's going to use.

threads.com: how would one go about starting a pirate radio station?

last_replies.name: Former Pirate Radio DJ
last_replies.com:
First off, find a frequency to operate on. If you're in a large metropolitan area, available frequencies in the FM band are going to be tough to find. Best way to do that is to drive around and tune throughout the band. Ideally, you'll want something with an open channel on both sides, but good luck.
The tricky part is determining how much power and antenna height you'll need. The simple way to figue is, if you can get an antenna about 20 - 30ft in the air, 10 watts can ideally give you a few mile radius. To double your distance, rither quadruple your power output or antenna eight.
Easiest antennas are simple 1/2 wave or 1/4 wave ground plane. You can find sites to tell you how to make those, but take a coat hanger, straighten out, and cut it to length. Use the formula 468/freq (in Mhz) then multiply by 12 to get inches for your length. Solder into a PL259 connector. Cut your radials same length and attach to the corners of the connector and bend at 45 degree angle.
20ft metal or Schedule 80 pipe works great for portable tower with a TV tripod. Use 50 ohm coax.
Transmitters can be found on E-bay. Avoid Chinese made units, for they're dirty and their singal splatters. Free Radio Berkeley still builds them by hand, but he's slow and it'll take months for him to finish.

Good luck, Anon. Read around the net to learn more. Be safe, be responsible.

It's raining.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503835

Construction fag.

Get a ladder and look up close. Also look from inside the attic and inside the home. Look at it from all angles. You can also use a hose to spray the area. Should be some trim or flashing that is letting it through. So try some light repairs and a strong exterior caulking material to waterproof it. You may just need the caulk and nothing else. This is a simple repair, don't be scared

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503835
Buy a tin of roofing tar from Home Depot and patch it yourself

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503861
This is good advice; also it's a common mistake to assume that a leak is directly above where it becomes visible but water often travels along framing, pipes, wiring and other materials before dropping down and coming into view, or it might pool up until it reaches the level of a gap that lets it escape and fall.
That's both potentially good and bad as far as finding and solving the problem, the point is though that a leak that appears at the bottom of the roof or under it in/on a wall or window or floor may be from a hole at the tippy top of the roof peak and running down, and not necessarily straight down.
Back tracing it to its source is the first step, and can take time if it's not obvious or theres not enough rain to trigger it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503918
A bath fan isn't going to have any noticeable effect on the air in your garage, they just move such a small amount of air. Most bath exhaust fans move like 50-100 CFM, even the heavier duty ones might only do 150CFM. I would recommend instead an in-line duct fan like in this pic that can move more like 600-900 CFM.

Install a couple of 12x12 HVAC returns in the ceiling at opposite ends of the garage and connect them with some 10-12 inch flex duct. Then put a 10-12 inch inline fan somewhere in the duct between them, probably close to the middle of the duct run to minimize noise. If the fan has enough CFM it should do a decent job at circulating the air. As an added bonus you could put an air filter in the return on the intake side if you wanted.

Make sure to use insulated flex duct, if it's not insulated it will just leech heat from your attic and turn the garage into an oven in the summer.

last_replies.com:
>>2503248
That's called level winding (or is a type of level winding*) and is done with a winder (aka a "spooler") with a guide that moves across the open face of the spool or bobbin as it rotates...it's a fairly common feature in some styles of fishing reels and cable winches and you can get them for yarn making and winding bobbins for things like weaving-
https://hansencrafts.com/cherry-woolee-winder/
https://myautowinder.com/
Simple ones loke in fishing reels use a direct gear drive to move the guide as the main axle spins, really sophisticated ones for manufacturing have sensors that adjust the guide motion and other factors as the material diameter increases, which is how the ones like your pic are so perfect-

"In spooling or level-wind applications, material is wound onto a spool. As the material's diameter changes on the supply spool, and on the the take-up spool, it’s critical to maintain the proper speed of each spool. Encoders provide the motion feedback to help maintain that speed.

Encoder feedback also helps monitor the length of material and helps maintain the proper tension on the material to avoid stretching, breaking or winding too tightly or loosely. "

https://www.encoder.com/spooling-level-wind

*specifically it's "cross wound" and here's a whole thing on why that might be done-

https://archaicarcane.com/standing-at-a-crossroads-thread-cross-wound-vs-stack-wound/comment-page-1/

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: I want to get my theoreticals in order and get some general knowledge. What would you recommend? I know practice is best and I am beginning a course next week, but reading hurt no one.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503385
The best online resource in the US for what you want are the Weldingweb forums which have many professionals and are noob-friendly. There are threads on how to prepare for school and what to bring. If you've already bought a few tools you may find others useful.

Make sure you can see at welding ranges. If you haven't a recent eye exam get one and remember optometrists can write multiple prescriptions at one visit. I wear separate glasses for near vision and driving. Know what "cheaters" (plain magnifying lenses) are. Know the location of your local welding suppliers and visit them.

Different people prefer different tints and shade levels. I mostly weld with shade 9 gold or blue tinted lenses.

Have spare gloves (welding gloves are consumables) so you don't interrupt booth time replacing them. Have spare clear cover lenses for whatever helmet you wear because it's typical to expend one a day. You need to see to weld. Dress for work not the block and remember whatever you wear gets a spark bath.

A large visegrip plier is quite handy (I weld T-handles, just some 1/4" scrap rod, to the adjusting knob to use it with gloves and because tightening the handle is vastly more powerful than manual squeeze.

See what the school issues for tools. Some don't issue small angle grinders because students destroy shit. Minimum personal grinder size should be a smallish bodied 6" to use thin kerf cutting wheels as wells a 4-1/2" rocks. If your school doesn't issue flap discs and you're not poor feel free to bring some. A rugged plastic bucket is the usual welder tote with an added rope handle. There's more but go here and read your arse off and that will be sufficient for the weekend.

https://weldingweb.com/vbb/forums/1-WeldingWeb-Disciplines

Bongs can goto migwelding.uk for the equipment differences. Later on I advise learning how all your equipment works because in the field you'll need to care for it.

>>2503146
>You are utterly full of shit, parroting the nonsensical "tonewood" bullshit.
Agreed and the entire heavy/dense = better thing and the "sympathetic resonance kills sustain" argument is pulled from the deepest recesses of his ass too.
Fact is that woods used in instruments are often chosen for structural and wear and stability and working qualities far more than for subtle nuance of tone, and where they are used to affect tonal and other qualities like sustain, crisp attack, etc. they are often used in combinations of "better" more exotic species and "lesser" quality woods to fine tune resonance and other qualities in certain frequency ranges.
Cedar is very soft and not dense and is used all the time in acoustics for guitars used in music that favors its sonic qualities, like classical guitar.
Some highly prized woods like mahogany sound like shit if you build an entire guitar out of them, and need a super stiff dense wood like a maple or ebony fingerboard or body cap to give it any attack and brightness at all.
Conversely an all hard maple guitar will be all bite and attack and treble with minimal depth and warmth.

tl;dr: sustain isn't everything and there is such a thing as too much of any "good" sonic quality in a guitar; balance is what matters...but only if the thing is structurally sound and stable, which matters most.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I've built an electric kit, generic inexpensive tele style. The only woodworking I had to do with it was shape the headstock blank. Did alright but I got some splintering, probably because I went yolo with a tenon saw - I'm not much of a carpenter - but enough sanding solved the worst of the damage. For me most of the work went into the paintjob, in that I wanted to get a really good solid finish, which I achieved to my satisfaction, over months of spraying, drying, sanding, spraying, drying, sanding, etc.

The rest of the build was just bolt the parts together, so nothing complicated. Finished the neck with Danish oil, had to get a set of files to adjust the nut, try and get the whole thing set up nice. It's not a great player, or else I'd look to invest in better electronics than the cheapo stuff that came with the kit, but it's fine. Reckon it'll make a nephew a nice first guitar Christmas present or something.

I'm sure I could probably spend some more time working on the set-up to try and get a better action out of it - what's nice with a cheap kit is that I'm not at all concerned with giving the truss-rod a good crank to see what happens; if it snaps the neck I can just replace it, or even take my first foray into repair.

Reckon my next project would be along the lines of doing a strip and respray. I've got an old genero-caster hanging around that plays well but the electrics are shot, might make the perfect victim.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2503043
Training dogs isn't that hard if you know some basic principles and avoid counterproductive methods. People who do classes tend to expect them to magically work without any extra effort; the key to any dog training being effective and sticking is to spend the right amount of time working with them, and at the right time in their development.
How much time they need to get commands or remember them, or how long a session they will tolerate before losing interest or becoming defiant just for fun depends a lot on the breed, which is another reason one size fits all classes may have limited value on their own.
But assuming you don't start too early with advanced stuff or wait until bad habits have to be unlearned, just spending the time and running through and building on basic obedience skills in a calm manner will get the typical dog used to doing what's expected of him, assuming you are *very* consistent with signals and instructions.
I mention signals first because contrary to what most people assume, using hand signals can be more effective than voice commands since dogs communicate visually. You can teach both at the same time but often when they get squirrely its the hand signal that will cut through whatever distracting them and get their attention.
They're like toddlers, and will try to interpret your voice for an angle to work and either ignore you as unserious if you try to be nice, or pout and refuse in a battle of wills if they think you aren't being nice enough.
Visual signals avoids all that and especially when more than one person will be giving commands.
But like little kids they will play any inconsistency for all they can, so you have to insist on it among the people involved, which is often more difficult than training the animal.
